newsitem.title: GERMANY: EU to seek subsidy-free farm exports - Fischler aide.
newsitem.headline: EU to seek subsidy-free farm exports - Fischler aide.

text.p: European farmers should respond to growing world food demand through exports free of subsidies, said Rudolf Strohmeyer, deputy head of European Union Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler's cabinet on Wednesday.
"Under trade liberalisation, we will have to open our own markets but we also gain access to new markets," he said at a seminar organised by grain trade paper Ernaehrungsdienst.
"We can't be on the defensive but we must emphasise our strengths and that presupposes exports without rebates."
Strohmeyer also said the EU's farm reform process, begun in a 1992 package of price and volume cuts, needed to be taken further and extended to products left out so far.
"We also need income aid to farmers under farm reform rules to be decoupled from production targets -- we need more market and less price support," he said.
Monies saved this way should be spent on the financing of infrastructure and environment measures, which member states should help finance.
With a lean farm sector, the EU would be well-equipped to make maximum demands in the new world trade round in 1999 rather than being attacked for protectionism.
This was essential to gain access to growing world food markets, especially in Asia, where purchasing power was also rising rapidly.
"We can't afford to lose our share in the world food market," said Strohmeyer.
The EU is the world's fourth largest farm exporter.

Strohmeyer added Eastern European countries awaiting EU accession should not be allowed income transfers in return for production cuts because their earnings would rise, not fall, when they entered the single market pricing structure.
